Emil Artin ( 1898 – 1962 ) was an Austrian mathematician of Armenian descent. Artin was one of the leading mathematicians of the twentieth century. He is best known for his work on algebraic number theory, contributing largely to class field theory and a new construction of L-functions. He also contributed to the pure theories of rings, groups, and fields. Along with Emmy Noether, he is considered the founder of modern abstract algebra. Emil Artin, a prominent mathematician of the 20th century, made significant contributions to various fields of mathematics, particularly in algebraic number theory and group theory. Some of his key contributions include: 1. Artin's Reciprocity Law: This is perhaps his most famous work, a central part of class field theory. It generalizes the law of quadratic reciprocity and shows a deep connection between Galois groups and ideal class groups in number fields. 2. Artin L-functions: These are a generalization of Dirichlet L-functions in number theory. They play a crucial role in the study of the distribution of prime numbers. 3. Artin's Conjecture: He made conjectures about the L-functions, which have been influential in the development of number theory. 4. Brauer–Artin Theorem: In collaboration with Richard Brauer, Artin worked on the representation theory of finite groups, which led to significant developments in modern algebra. 5. Artin–Wedderburn Theorem: This theorem is a foundational result in the theory of simple algebras and semisimple rings. 6. Artin's Theorem on Primitive Roots: This theorem gives a criterion for when a number is a primitive root modulo n, which is an important concept in number theory. 7. Contributions to Algebraic Geometry: Artin also made significant contributions to the field of algebraic geometry, influencing its modern development. 8. Artin Groups and Artinian Rings: These concepts, named after him, are fundamental in the study of algebraic structures and ring theory. Artin's work has had a profound and lasting impact on the field of mathematics, influencing numerous areas and inspiring generations of mathematicians. His ability to connect different mathematical concepts and his deep insights into algebra and number theory are widely celebrated. https://lnkd.in/dtju_t4Z AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Peter Scholze 1987 is a German mathematician known for his work in arithmetic algebraic geometry. He has been a professor at the University of Bonn since 2012 and director at the Max Planck Institute for Mathematics since 2018. He has been called one of the leading mathematicians in the world. He won the Fields Medal in 2018. These are some of his most remarkable contributions: 1. Perfectoid Spaces: - Scholze's development of perfectoid spaces has been a major breakthrough in arithmetic algebraic geometry, providing a unifying framework to study the arithmetic of different number fields. 2. Advances in the Langlands Program: - His work has significantly advanced the Langlands program, particularly in understanding the connections between number theory, geometry, and representation theory. 3. p-adic Hodge Theory: - Scholze, along with Laurent Fargues, has been pioneering a new approach to p-adic Hodge theory, which is expected to have profound implications for the geometric Langlands program. 4. Tilting Correspondence: - The tilting correspondence discovered by Scholze is a fundamental principle that allows for the comparison of geometric structures over complex and p-adic fields. 5. Condensed Mathematics: - Together with Dustin Clausen, Scholze is developing the framework of condensed mathematics, which aims to refine the foundations of topology and geometry to better suit modern mathematical needs, especially in the context of p-adic analysis. 6. Liquid Tensor Experiment: - Scholze has initiated the Liquid Tensor Experiment, challenging the mathematical community to formalize a part of his work in analytic geometry using a proof assistant, which is a significant step towards the computer-aided formalization of complex mathematical theories. 7. Awards and Recognition: - His numerous awards, including the Fields Medal, underscore the impact of his deep contributions to mathematics. Peter Scholze's work is characterized by its originality, depth, and the broad implications it has for the field of mathematics. His contributions continue to influence a wide range of mathematical disciplines, and his ongoing research is closely watched by the mathematical community for further groundbreaking results. https://lnkd.in/ddwbxK_T AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

William Paul Thurston ( 1946 – 2012 ) was an American mathematician. He was a pioneer in the field of low-dimensional topology and was awarded the Fields Medal in 1982 for his contributions to the study of 3-manifolds. Thurston was a professor of mathematics at Princeton University, University of California, Davis, and Cornell University. He was also a director of the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute. Some of his most notable scientific contributions include: 1. Thurston's Geometrization Conjecture: This was a far-reaching conjecture about the geometric structure of three-dimensional manifolds. It proposed that every compact 3-manifold can be decomposed into pieces that have one of eight types of geometric structures. This conjecture was later proven by Grigori Perelman and was a major breakthrough in three-dimensional topology. 2. Thurston's work on Foliations: Thurston made substantial advancements in the study of foliations, which are geometric structures that generalize the notion of "surfaces" in higher dimensions. His work provided new insights and methods for understanding these structures. 3. Hyperbolic geometry: Thurston was a pioneer in the study of 3-dimensional hyperbolic geometry. He developed tools and theories that showed how hyperbolic geometry plays a crucial role in the understanding of 3-manifolds. 4. Teichmüller theory and surfaces: He made significant contributions to Teichmüller theory, which is a branch of complex analysis that deals with the geometry of Riemann surfaces and their moduli spaces. 5. Thurston’s Orbifold Theorem: This theorem is a generalization of the hyperbolization theorem for Haken manifolds and played an important role in 3-dimensional topology and geometric group theory. 6. Educational Contributions: Beyond his research, Thurston was also known for his educational contributions. He emphasized the importance of intuition and understanding in mathematics, rather than just technical prowess. His lectures and writings have inspired many mathematicians. Thurston's work had a profound impact on the field of mathematics, reshaping our understanding of the geometric and topological properties of spaces. His insights and methods continue to influence current research in these areas. Pierre René, Viscount Deligne ( 1944 ) is a Belgian mathematician. He is best known for work on the Weil conjectures, leading to a complete proof in 1973. Has made significant contributions to several areas of mathematics, especially in algebraic geometry and number theory. He is the winner of the 2013 Abel Prize, 2008 Wolf Prize, 1988 Crafoord Prize, and 1978 Fields Medal. From 1970 until 1984, Deligne was a permanent member of the IHÉS staff. In 1984, Deligne moved to the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. His most notable achievements include: 1. Proof of the Weil Conjectures: Deligne's work on the Weil conjectures is perhaps his most celebrated contribution. These conjectures, proposed by André Weil, relate the number of solutions of equations over finite fields to the topology of the equations' complex solutions. Deligne's proof of the last and deepest of these conjectures, the "Weil conjecture on Tamagawa numbers," earned him the Fields Medal in 1978. 2. Deligne Cohomology: In algebraic geometry, Deligne developed a theory of mixed Hodge structures and introduced what is now known as Deligne cohomology. This work has had a profound impact on the field, providing deep insights into the nature of algebraic varieties. 3. Work on Hodge Theory and Singularities: Deligne made significant contributions to Hodge theory, which is a central tool in modern algebraic geometry. His work helped in understanding the role of singularities in various contexts, which has applications in many areas of mathematics. 4. Contributions to the Langlands Program: He has also made important contributions to the Langlands program, a set of deep conjectures connecting number theory and representation theory. 5. Tannakian Categories: Deligne's work on Tannakian categories has been influential in representation theory and algebraic geometry. This concept provides a framework for understanding linear algebraic groups and their representations. 6. Kazhdan–Lusztig Conjectures: Deligne, along with David Kazhdan and George Lusztig, worked on the Kazhdan–Lusztig conjectures, which have deep implications in representation theory and algebraic geometry. 7. Moduli Spaces and Stacks: He has done significant work in the study of moduli spaces and stacks, which are important in the study of algebraic surfaces and other geometric structures. Deligne's work, characterized by deep insight and technical mastery, has had a wide-ranging impact across mathematics, influencing both the development of new theories and the solution of long-standing problems. https://lnkd.in/daEpuZGF Sources: Wiki, Yves Laszlo, Raphael Douady, IAS, IAs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Marius Sophus Lie ( 1842 – 1899 ) was a Norwegian mathematician. He largely created the theory of continuous symmetry and applied it to the study of geometry and differential equations. He also made substantial contributions to the development of algebra. Here are some of his key contributions: 1. Theory of Continuous Groups (Lie Groups): Lie's most significant contribution was the development of the theory of continuous groups, now known as Lie groups. These are groups of transformations that are continuous, in contrast to the discrete groups studied in other parts of mathematics. Lie groups have become fundamental in many areas of mathematics and theoretical physics, particularly in the study of symmetry. 2. Lie Algebras: Associated with Lie groups are Lie algebras, which are algebraic structures that capture the essence of the groups' infinitesimal transformations. Lie algebras have become a crucial tool in various areas of mathematics and physics, including quantum mechanics and string theory. 3. Transformation Groups: Lie extensively worked on transformation groups, which are groups of geometric transformations. His work laid the groundwork for the modern approach to symmetries in geometry and physics. 4. Differential Geometry: Lie's work in the field of differential geometry was pioneering. He applied the concept of continuous groups to the study of differential equations and geometric structures, which was a novel approach at the time. 5. Integration of Differential Equations: Lie developed new methods for the integration of differential equations based on his theory of continuous groups. This had a significant impact on the field of differential equations. 6. Lie's Third Theorem: This theorem, one of his most important results, states that to every finite-dimensional Lie algebra over the field of real numbers, there corresponds a Lie group. This theorem bridged the abstract study of Lie algebras with the more concrete study of Lie groups. 7. Influence on Other Fields: Lie's theories have influenced various fields, including algebra, geometry, and the theory of differential equations. They have also played a crucial role in the development of modern physics, particularly in areas such as particle physics and cosmology. Lie's work was characterized by a deep understanding of the interconnectedness of different areas of mathematics and a vision that saw the unifying role of symmetry in mathematics and physics. His contributions continue to influence contemporary research and are considered foundational in several areas of modern mathematics and theoretical physics. Talking about unsung math heroes, it's hard not to mention the 19th-century French mathematician Pierre Wantzel. In a single paper published in 1837, Wantzel solved not one, but two problems that mathematicians had been attempting to solve for many millennia! What were these problems? Ancient Greeks were obsessed with so-called ruler-and-compass geometrical constructions, where achieving a certain goal was only allowed using those two instruments (the ruler was supposed to be unmarked). Consequently, there are numerous problems, such as constructing a square with an area twice that of the original square or another regular polygon, creating a line with a length equal to the square root of the original one, and so on. Two particularly notorious problems that stumped the best mathematicians for many millennia were: a. Trisecting an angle: dividing a given angle into three equal parts. b. Doubling a cube: constructing a cube with twice the volume of the original one. Now, in his paper, Wantzel had just proved that these tasks were impossible to achieve! How did he do it? Wantzel converted this purely geometrical problem into an algebraic one. He demonstrated that solving both would require finding a solution of a cubic equation, but only quadratic ones are solvable by geometrical means. Today, we associate these kinds of proofs with the work of another French genius, Évariste Galois, who single-handedly created a new branch of mathematics we call modern (or abstract) algebra. Galois wrote virtually all his work in one night on May 30, 1831, before his duel, where he was fatally wounded, dying a day later at the age of 20. Nevertheless, his work was only published in 1848, giving Wantzel credit for the original solution of these two puzzles. For someone who solved two millennial problems, Wantzel has certainly not received enough credit. In fact, his work was never mentioned in any publication for about 50 years! Even today, Wantzel’s name is not a household one, despite all the hard work he put in. And Wantzel did work hard. If your parents or your teachers ever told you that no one died from overwork, Wantzel could have been used as a counterexample - he literally worked himself to death. His early demise at the age of 33 was attributed to his unhealthy work habits, including working through the night with only a few hours of sleep and consuming colossal amounts of coffee. Let’s then remember Wantzel as a man who managed to solve two of the hardest problems in the history of mathematics by thinking outside the box and as someone who serves as an example of the importance of work-life balance for everyone.
